abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Minas Gerais Water
            Quality and Pollution Control Project is rated satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project design of this project
            include: 1) A clear distinction should be made between a
            long-term project/program goal and a short- to medium-term
            project objective. 2) Monitoring and evaluation indicators
            should be better designed to capture the impact of
            incremental and partial project intervention. This project
            was complex and risky. If future projects are to adopt the
            comprehensive river basin approach, the following lessons
            should be incorporated into the project design and
            preparation process: a) The project should be a part of a
            long-term strategic program. b) To facilitate creation of
            the river basin agency, introduction of water use and
            pollution fees, and drafting and enactment of the necessary
            legal framework, the project should make budget provision
            for the agency, promote creation of a transitional
            institution or "embryo" unit that would take the
            lead in the creation of the agency, ensure that users and
            communities are well informed, and ensure that the legal
            covenants applicable are realistic and so do not affect the
            consensus building process adversely. c) Project
            Coordination Unit personnel should be selected not only on
            technical qualifications but also on capacity to coordinate
            a range of government agencies at different levels to lead
            the reform agenda. d) Risks should be identified and
            addressed upfront.
